sen.j: 川崎 鑰之助（かわさき かぎのすけ、生没年不詳）は、日本の戦国時代 (日本)の兵法家。
sen.e: Kaginosuke KAWASAKI (year of birth and death unknown) was a military strategist in the sengoku period of Japan (period of warring states).
Kaginosuke KAWASAKI (year of birth and death unknown) was a military strategist during the Sengoku period of Japan (period of warring states).
Kaginosuke KAWASAKI (year of birth and death unknown) was a military strategist during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

sen.j: 東軍流剣術を開いたとされる。
sen.e: He was regarded to have established Togun-ryu school swordplay.
He was regarded to have established Togun-ryu school of Kenjutsu (the art of the sword).
He was regarded to have established Togun-ryu school of Kenjutsu (the art of the sword).
His name was Tokimori.
His given name was Tokimori.
His given name was Tokimori.
He was also called Yukimori or Kiyosada.
He was also called Yukimori or Kiyosada.
He was also called Yukimori or Kiyosada.
He was commonly called Kaginosuke.
He was commonly known as 賀義助 (Kaginosuke), which uses different kanji characters from 鑰之助 (Kaginosuke).
He was commonly known as 賀義助 (Kaginosuke), which uses different kanji characters from 鑰之助 (Kaginosuke).

sen.j: 越前国朝倉氏の御用人、川崎時定（新九郎）の子だった。
sen.e: He was a child of Tokisada KAWASAKI (Shinkuro), Goyonin (officer handling domestic economy) of the Asakura clan in Echizen province
sen.cmt: →読み方不明ですが→Tokisada KAWASAKIと訳出しています。一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: He was the son of Tokisada KAWASAKI (Shinkuro), a Goyonin (officer handling domestic economy) of the Asakura clan in the Echizen Province.
He was the son of Tokisada KAWASAKI (Shinkuro), a Goyonin (officer handling domestic economy) of the Asakura clan in the Echizen Province.

sen.j: 父時定は京八流の達人だったという。
sen.e: His father, Tokisada was excellent at kyohachi-ryu school (one school of swordplay known as Kyoto eight) swordplay.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: His father Tokisada was skilled at the Kyohachi-ryu school (one of eight schools of Kenjutsu in Kyoto) of Kenjutsu.
His father Tokisada was skilled at the Kyohachi-ryu school (one of eight schools of Kenjutsu in Kyoto) of Kenjutsu.

sen.j: 鑰之助は13歳のころから父に学んだ。
sen.e: Kaginosuke started to learn swordplay around thirteen.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Kaginosuke started to learn kenjutsu when he was 13.
Kaginosuke started to learn kenjutsu when he was 13.

sen.j: さらに槍術を富田午生に、剣術を富田勢源に学んだ。
sen.e: He learned the art of the spearman ship from Ushifu TOMITA, and learned swordplay from Seigen TODA.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: He learned sojutsu (the art of the spear) from Ushifu TOMITA, and learned kenjutsu from Seigen TODA.
He learned sojutsu (the art of the spear) from Ushifu TOMITA, and learned kenjutsu from Seigen TODA.

sen.j: 17歳で、真柄真基（十郎三郎）、村上長孝（庄蔵）とともに朝倉の「鬼若三勇士」とうたわれたという。
sen.e: At the age of seventeen, he was known as one of `three iron-hearted young brave samurai' in Asakura together with other two; Sanemoto MAGARA (Juro-Saburo), Nagataka MURAKAMI (Shozo).
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: At the age of 17, he was known as one of the `three iron-hearted young brave samurai' of Asakura along with Sanemoto MAGARA (Juro-Saburo) and Nagataka MURAKAMI (Shozo).
At the age of 17, he was known as one of the `three iron-hearted young brave samurai' of Asakura along with Sanemoto MAGARA (Juro-Saburo) and Nagataka MURAKAMI (Shozo).

sen.j: 『日本剣豪100選』の綿谷雪はこれは虚構かもしれないとしている。
sen.e: However, Kiyoshi WATATANI, the writer of "the 100 best swordsmen in Japan" regarded it as a possible fiction.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Kiyoshi WATATANI, the writer of "the 100 best swordsmen in Japan," however, regarded that as possibly being fiction.
Kiyoshi WATATANI, the writer of "the 100 best swordsmen in Japan," however, regarded that as possibly being fiction.

sen.j: 父時定の浪人後、比叡山の東軍権僧正のもとにあずけられた。
sen.e: After his father turned a ronin(masterless samurai, he was kept under Togun (Eastern camp) gon no sojo (a highest ranking priest, next to a sojo) in Mt. Hiei.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。東軍権僧正→定訳不明ですが→Togun gon no sojo と訳出しています。
sen.e: After Kaginosuke's father turned ronin (a masterless samurai), Kaginosuke was looked after by Togun (Eastern camp) Gon no sojo (a highest ranking priest, next to a sojo) on Mt. Hiei.
After Kaginosuke's father turned ronin (a masterless samurai), Kaginosuke was looked after by Togun (Eastern camp) Gon no sojo (a highest ranking priest, next to a sojo) on Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: この地で刀術の秘伝を学び、一流を開創したとされる。
sen.e: He was said to have learned inherited secret teachings of art of wielding swords in there, and founded a school.
sen.cmt: he 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: He was said to have learned inherited secret teachings of art of wielding swords in there, and founded a school.
He was said to have learned inherited secret teachings of art of wielding swords in there, and founded a school.

sen.j: 鑰之助は自ら流名を称することはなかったが、世人からは「東軍者」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Kaginosuke didn't refer to himself by 流名, but people called him `Togun (Eastern camp) person.'
sen.cmt: 流名→定訳不明のため原文のままとしています。
sen.e: Kaginosuke didn't refer to himself by 流名, but people called him `a person of the Togun (Eastern camp).'
sen.cmt: the reading and explanation of 流名 is not provided
sen.e: Kaginosuke didn't refer to himself by 流名, but people called him `a person of the Togun' (Eastern camp).

sen.j: 『武芸小伝』によると、鑰之助は上野国白雲山（妙義山の古名）の神に祈って東軍流を起こしたともいう。
sen.e: According to "Bugei Shoden," Kaginosuke founded Togun-ryu school, praying for the God of Hakuunzan (Mt. Hakuun) in Kozuke Province (the old name of Mt. Myogi).
According to the "Bugei Shoden," Kaginosuke prayed to the God of Mt. Hakuun (the old name of Mt. Myogi) in Kozuke Province, and founded the Togun-ryu school.
sen.cmt: rewording;the explanation of 武芸小伝 is not provided
sen.e: According to the "Bugei Shoden," Kaginosuke prayed to the God of Mt. Hakuun (the old name of Mt. Myogi) in Kozuke Province, and founded the Togun-ryu school.

sen.j: 東軍流の道統は、東軍権僧正を開祖と仰ぎ、川崎鑰之助 - 川崎五郎 - 川崎太郎 - 川崎宗勝（次郎太夫）と継承された。
sen.e: The founder of the Togun-ryu school was the Togun (Eastern camp) gon no sojo (a highest ranking priest, next to a sojo), and it was passed down from Kaginosuke KAWASAKI, Goro KAWASAKI, Taro KAWASAKI, to Munekatsu KAWASAKI (Jiro-dayu).

Starting with the Togun (Eastern camp) Gon no sojo (a highest ranking priest, next to a sojo), who was the founder of the Togun-ryu school, the ways of the school was passed down from Kaginosuke KAWASAKI to Goro KAWASAKI to Taro KAWASAKI and to Munekatsu KAWASAKI (Jiro-dayu).

Starting with the Togun (Eastern camp) Gon no sojo (a highest ranking priest, next to a sojo), who was the founder of the Togun-ryu school, the ways of the school was passed down from Kaginosuke KAWASAKI to Goro KAWASAKI to Taro KAWASAKI and to Munekatsu KAWASAKI (Jiro-dayu).

sen.j: 宗勝が回国修行中、武蔵国忍（現埼玉県行田市）において多数の敵に襲われながらも切り抜けたことで、その武勇が知られるようになった。
sen.e: Togun-ryu school became known through the heroic story; when Munekatsu who was traveling for training was attacked by a large number of enemies in Oshi, Musashi Province (Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture in the present day), he got through using his Togun-ryu school swordplay techniques.

The Togun-ryu school became known through an heroic story, which speaks of Munekatsu, who was traveling during his training, was attacked by a large number of enemies in Oshi, Musashi Province (present day Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture), but miraculously made his way through his enemies using his Togun-ryu school Kenjutsu techniques.

The Togun-ryu school became known through an heroic story, which speaks of Munekatsu, who was traveling during his training, was attacked by a large number of enemies in Oshi, Musashi Province (present day Gyoda City, Saitama Prefecture), but miraculously made his way through his enemies using his Togun-ryu school Kenjutsu techniques.
